title: Volkswagen CFO Plans to Target New Investors With Green Bond
summary: The bond, which still needs final approval, would be the auto maker's first under a new green finance framework launched in March. German car maker Volkswagen AG plans to target new investors with a green bond in excess of €1 billion ($1.18 billion) in September, the company's first under a sustainable finance framework launched in March.

title: Principals Warn New York City Faces Teacher Shortage for Reopening Plan
summary: School leaders have demanded more guidance on how to staff the city's hybrid model of classroom and online education. New York City principals are warning of a teacher shortage as they work to comply with a new district policy their union says will require thousands more teachers during a hiring freeze.

title: Low Rates Forever!
summary: The Federal Reserve takes a leap into the monetary unknown.. Jerome Powell's Federal Reserve on Thursday released a long-awaited review of its policy framework, and it's a mixed bag. On the upside, the central bank will no longer throttle the economy whenever "too many" Americans have jobs. On the downside, the Fed may never raise interest rates again.

title: Walmart Joins With Microsoft in Race to Purchase TikTok
summary: Microsoft bid seen as front-runner for potential deal that could be announced next week; TikTok is asking $30 billion for its U.S. operations. The race to capture TikTok's U.S. operations took a sharp turn Thursday, as Walmart Inc. said it is joining Microsoft Corp.'s bid for the popular video-sharing app after other deep-pocketed suitors dropped out of the running.

title: Pelosi Wants No Debates
summary: The Speaker walks point to protect Biden from going against Trump.. Nowadays politicians so frequently say the opposite of what they mean that they can't be taken at face value. So it may be with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's assertion on Thursday that Joe Biden shouldn't deign to debate President Trump this fall.

title: Some California Sanity on Housing
summary: A case study in why homes are unaffordable, and a possible solution.. Good news from California, of all places. The city of Santa Ana is trying to do something about its housing shortage, and other cities in the state should take note.

title: New U.S. Coronavirus Cases Rise, as Hurricane Laura Affects Testing
summary: Total infections have passed 5.85 million nationwide, and more than 180,000 have died. The number of new coronavirus infections in the U.S. increased for a third straight day, as Hurricane Laura pummeled the Gulf Coast, stirring fears about how the storm might make it harder to contain the virus.

title: RNC Guide: Schedule, Speakers and How to Watch
summary: This year's Republican National Convention is mostly virtual due to the coronavirus, with parts taking place in Charlotte, N.C., and Washington, D.C.. This year's Republican National Convention is mostly virtual, with only official party business taking place in Charlotte, N.C. President Trump initially moved the prime-time events to Jacksonville, Fla., then canceled that change due to coronavirus concerns.

title: 'Robin's Wish': The Punchline Was Courage
summary: A documentary offers a moving portrait of Robin Williams and a harrowing account of the disease that ravaged him.. By now the circumstances of Robin Williams's death are settled fact. He didn't kill himself because of addiction or depression, though he'd made stops at those way stations in the past. He put an end to his rich, joyous life because he was suffering, hideously and terminally, from diffuse Lewy body dementia, a rare and incurable degenerative disease that ravages both body and brain. Tylor Norwood's "Robin's Wish," a documentary streaming on digital platforms and VOD, examines the nature and impact of the disease in useful, if harrowing detail. The film also offers a portrait in unfathomable courage. It's a horror story shackled to a hero's journey in which a man with a surpassingly fertile mind feels himself-his deepest, essential self-coming inexorably, inexplicably undone.

title: 'Lingua Franca' Review: Looking for Love
summary: A Filipina caregiver hopes to find a husband, and thereby a green card, in Isabel Sandoval's touching feature.. An outer calm belies the inner turmoil of the Filipina caregiver at the center of Isabel Sandoval's "Lingua Franca," a small and affecting feature set mostly in the Brighton Beach neighborhood of Brooklyn. (It's streaming on Netflix.) Her name is Olivia, she is played-with extraordinary understatement-by the filmmaker, and she brings seemingly inexhaustible patience to the job of looking after Olga (Lynn Cohen), an elderly Russian woman who is often befuddled though not defeated by dementia.

title: 'Critical' Ethnic Studies Returns to California
summary: The state's new curriculum prefers victimization to minority achievement, and Marxism to liberal values.. A year after it was sent back to the drawing board, California's ethnic-studies model curriculum is back. The last version, released in May 2019, was radical and jargon-laced. Even many progressives found it fringy. On Aug. 13, the state Education Department presented a new, toned-down draft to the curriculum commission. Not only does it suffer from the same conceptual problems as before, but during their meeting, commissioners directed the Education Department to resuscitate unpopular parts cut from the 2019 draft.

title: 'The Personal History of David Copperfield' Review: Timelessness Made Tired
summary: Dev Patel stars in Armando Iannucci's adaptation of the Dickens classic.. Before turning to Armando Iannucci's "The Personal History of David Copperfield," a cheerfully meta and multiracial reimagining of the Dickens classic starring Dev Patel, let me say that I loved the filmmaker's previous feature, "The Death of Stalin," for its darkly absurdist humor. I wanted to embrace this one for its bright spirit, its eagerness to please and its audacity in taking the novel's essential elements and scattering them around a time-hopping, turn-on-a-farthing narrative structure. Mr. Patel is certainly up for every moment of every scene, a lively, quick-witted presence as the adult David. Truth be told, though, the film, which Mr. Iannucci directed from a screenplay he wrote with Simon Blackwell, is blissed out on its own cleverness and ultimately exhausting. (Showtimes in theaters-yes, actual theaters-around the country can be found at copperfieldtickets.searchlightpictures.com.)

title: Where August Is the Cruelest Month
summary: Louisianans are reminded of nature's devastating power with tragic regularity.. Baton Rouge, La.

title: Clothing Retailers Go Casual as Consumers Spurn Dressy Clothes
summary: Consumers shifted to 'soft and cozy merchandise,' Abercrombie & Fitch CEO says. Americans' newfound love for sweatpants has apparel retailers racing to get casual, as they try to kick-start sales decimated by coronavirus-related store closures.

title: New York Has Witnessed a Mortgage Strike Before
summary: In 1929, when some Queens residents stopped paying, leaders didn't share AOC's view of government power.. New York is facing a crime wave and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has found the culprit: rent. People can't afford it and need money, "so they feel like they either need to shoplift some bread or go hungry," she said earlier this summer.

title: Where Liberty University Goes From Here
summary: The firing of Jerry Falwell Jr. should be the beginning of much deeper reforms.. Success can cover a multitude of sins-at least that's how it seemed to anyone observing Jerry Falwell Jr.'s behavior when he served as president of Liberty University. His resignation this week was long overdue, and Liberty can now begin regaining its place of prominence as a leading evangelical academic institution. It must start with recommitting to what drew so many young people there in the first place: its reputation for training champions for Christ.

title: The GOP's Wide-Open Arms
summary: A marginal increase in Trump's minority support could swing the vote in key states.. The Republican Party that presented itself to the nation this week had a wide and welcoming look. Some in the GOP think that look could make the difference in November.

title: 'Losers' Review: The Lessons of Defeat
summary: To the man who threw the pennant-losing pitch to Bobby Thomson, a priest said it could happen to anyone. 'Yes, father, but why did it have to be me?'. Floyd Patterson, who was the heavyweight boxing champion when people cared about such things, began to talk about himself in a way he never had before when he started losing. What followed his two knockouts by Sonny Liston was hurt-"a confused hurt-not a physical hurt." It was the hurt of having to leave the ring "and face those people." Imagine, Floyd Patterson purchased false whiskers and a mustache to wear as a disguise. Yes, Floyd Patterson, as fearsome as any boxer ever, considered himself a coward.

title: Postmaster General Focused Too Narrowly on Trucking, Some Experts Say
summary: Sticking to tight schedules can save money, but logistics analysts say services can also slide. Logistics experts say Postmaster General Louis DeJoy's recent drive to make the U.S. Postal Service's operations more efficient appeared to overlook the impact on mail delivery at a time of considerable upheaval and growing demands on services.

title: Neiman Marcus Sues Marble Ridge Over Alleged Bid Rigging
summary: Bankruptcy watchdog says hedge fund's founder lobbied to prevent a competing bid for Neiman's online unit MyTheresa. Neiman Marcus Group Ltd. is suing Marble Ridge Capital LP after a bankruptcy watchdog said the hedge fund's founder illegally pressured an investment bank to drop its bid on a lucrative piece of the department-store chain's business so he could buy it himself.

title: Remington Won't Have to Answer Questions From Sandy Hook Families
summary: Lawyers for families of Connecticut school shooting victims can't probe bankrupt gunmaker's finances, judge says. A judge overseeing the bankruptcy of Remington Outdoor Co., the maker of the weapon used to kill 26 people, mostly children, at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012, barred lawyers for victims' families from probing the company's finances.

title: Publishers Brace for Impact From Apple's New Privacy Controls
summary: Media outlets worry the change in Apple's operating system will hurt ad sales at a critical moment for the industry. Privacy changes in Apple Inc.'s new operating system are sending ripples through the digital publishing world, with outlets that rely heavily on advertising bracing for a sizable drop in revenue from iPhone users.

title: Hertz Seeking Up to $1.5 Billion In Bankruptcy Financing
summary: Rental car company goes the traditional bankruptcy finance route after being forced to terminate controversial stock sale. Hertz Global Holdings Inc. is on the hunt for a bankruptcy loan totaling as much as $1.5 billion after regulators blocked the rental car company from pursuing a sale of what likely would be worthless stock, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Stalled Coronavirus-Aid Talks Test Schools
summary: Falling tax revenues and new costs are squeezing school districts, and lawmakers disagree on how much funding to provide. As schools start the year without more federal aid to help cover the costs of contending with a pandemic, academic officials are warning that vast budget shortfalls will further strain their districts unless Democrats and Republicans break their impasse on a new coronavirus-relief package.

title: New York Council Bill Would Amend Police Chokehold Law
summary: Amendment, proposed amid concerns about rising crime, would clarify reasons an officer could be prosecuted. A bill introduced in the New York City Council on Thursday would limit the reasons a police officer could be prosecuted for using a chokehold.

title: Fed's Elevation of Employment Goal Reflects a Changed World
summary: Central bank implies that unemployment can never be too low. With the revamp of its monetary policy framework, the Federal Reserve has subtly but clearly shifted its priorities away from inflation to employment.

title: U.S. Stocks Rise as Fed Signals Policy Shift
summary: The Fed said it will tolerate periods when inflation runs higher than 2% to even out periods when it has been below that mark. U.S. stocks rose Thursday after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said the central bank would abandon its policy of pre-emptively raising rates to head off inflation.

title: Americans Cut Back as Many Await Stimulus Checks
summary: Many people are spending less on groceries as federal unemployment stimulus remains on hold for most recipients. Americans are spending less money on groceries than they were in July, data show, a sign that they are hurting for cash as the federal unemployment stimulus remains on hold for most recipients. The extra $600 in weekly benefits that people without jobs were receiving expired in July. President Trump signed an executive order earlier this month that would provide an additional $400 a week in benefits. The program has been delayed because it requires states to reconfigure their unemployment systems and chip in $100 per person. Currently, three states are distributing the funds. Walmart executives said consumers are nervous about their finances and job security in the absence of stimulus aid, leading to cutbacks in spending. The trend has prompted Associated Food Stores to offer discounts. Food makers Kellogg Co. and Kraft Heinz said they are also planning to bring back discounts aimed at budget-conscious shoppers, as they try to keep the momentum they saw in recent months. The financial stress could push more middle-income consumers to shop at dollar stores, said Morgan Stanley retail analyst Simeon Gutman.

title: Xpeng, a Chinese Rival to Tesla, Raises $1.5 Billion in U.S. IPO
summary: Shares of electric-car maker jump 41% on the first day of trading in the U.S. Xpeng Inc., one of Tesla Inc.'s Chinese rivals, raised $1.5 billion through an initial public offering in the U.S., more than initially planned, because of high investor demand.

title: Robert Lighthizer's Plan to Reform the WTO
summary: The so-called "free trade" dogma that led the U.S. into trade disasters was anything but.. Regarding U.S. Trade Representative Robert E. Lighthizer's "How to Set World Trade Straight" (op-ed, Aug. 21): The so-called "free trade" dogma that led the U.S. into trade disasters was anything but. The term was cynically employed by its proponents to avoid the economically accurate term "reverse mercantilism." That policy deliberately gamed the governmentally established conditions of trade disproportionately to favor imports over exports. As just one example, the U.S. government itself calculated that the average tariff for American imports was just over 1%, the world's lowest by far, when the average faced by American exports was 40%. Every Econ 101 student learns that if you tax butter at 40%, and guns at 1%, you get more guns and less butter than the "free trade" result. Thus our massive trade deficits, with the consequent job losses, wealth transfers abroad and other pathologies weren't the natural results of "free trade" but the products of deliberately engineered "reverse mercantilism."

title: Hong Kong Officials Should Walk the Walk
summary: The letter from Chief Secretary Matthew Cheung Kin-chung (Aug. 24) shows a worrying lack of awareness of the impact the new National Security Law in Hong Kong is already having.. The letter from Chief Secretary Matthew Cheung Kin-chung (Aug. 24) shows a worrying lack of awareness of the impact the new National Security Law in Hong Kong is already having.

title: They See Themselves as Agents, Not Victims
summary: Tunku Varadarajan, as an immigrant himself, offers a much more positive description of immigrants than projected by the Democrats during the week of their national convention ("Democrats Make This Nonnative Restless,". Tunku Varadarajan, as an immigrant himself, offers a much more positive description of immigrants than projected by the Democrats during the week of their national convention ("Democrats Make This Nonnative Restless," op-ed, Aug. 22). Mr. Varadarajan portrays immigrants as people who come to America as the land of opportunity where they can and do realize their dreams as in no other place on earth, and not a place where racism denies them their future. His experience and observations show how successful our legal immigrants are in this country. This raises a difficult question: Why is it that immigrants, including black immigrants and their children, are more likely to thrive in this country than their nonimmigrant minority counterparts? Mr. Varadarajan provides the answer: Immigrants generally haven't bought the Democrats' portrayal of them "as victims-hapless people thwarted by 'systemic racism' and American injustice, moored forever in a netherworld of murk and fear."

title: Pre-Covid Federal Policy Discouraged Telemedicine
summary: This is a Clinton-era rule that should have never been implemented in the first place.. In his Aug. 24 letter, Gregory O. Ginn wonders why health-care providers didn't offer telemedicine years ago. Look no further than the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, which has defined a billable evaluation and management physician visit as one where the provider meets "face to face" with the patient. This 1995 requirement was updated once, to allow telemedicine visits only when the patient lives in a "remote" area, at least 25 miles from a physician office. The reason for such restrictions by CMS is to prevent billing fraud. This is a Clinton-era rule that should have never been implemented in the first place.

title: Joe Biden, Kamala Harris Reject Republicans' Criticism Over Civil Unrest
summary: 'You won't be safe in Joe Biden's America," Mike Pence says at GOP convention; Biden responds, 'This happens to be Donald Trump's America'. Democratic running mates Joe Biden and Kamala Harris rejected Republicans' characterization of them as soft on crime on Thursday and condemned President Trump's handling of unrest in parts of the country over racial injustice.

title: America's Energy Corridor Narrowly Averts Direct Hit From Laura
summary: Facilities along the Texas-Louisiana coast had closed and activated emergency procedures in advance of storm. Hurricane Laura narrowly missed the heart of America's fuel-making and chemicals infrastructure along the Gulf Coast, but a chlorine fire in Louisiana Thursday threatened the Lake Charles metro area.

title: Bon Appétit Names Dawn Davis as Editor in Chief
summary: Acclaimed book publisher and author to take over food magazine months after Adam Rapoport's departure. Condé Nast has named Dawn Davis as the new editor in chief of Bon Appétit, bringing in a prominent Black book-publishing executive and cookbook author to lead the renowned food magazine, which has been rocked by allegations of racial insensitivity and discrimination.

title: 'Fortnite' Fans Are Pushed to Choose Sides as Season 4 Starts
summary: Epic Games is banking on support from ardent gamers though some fear the company is risking goodwill in spat with Apple and Google. When season 4 of "Fortnite" launches Thursday, players like David Morell won't be able to log into the popular videogame from their iPhones.

title: Surging Laptop Demand Helps HP, Dell Amid Office-Spending Slump
summary: Consumers stuck at home during the pandemic also invest in new printers. Hot demand for laptops as people work and learn remotely helped HP Inc. and Dell Technologies Inc. soften the hit from a slowdown in office-equipment spending during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Bayer's Roundup Settlement Talks Hit New Setback
summary: Judge considers allowing litigation to restart after plaintiffs' lawyers say deals have been terminated or remain unsigned; Bayer says it can finalize settlements. Bayer AG's $10.9 billion settlement to resolve lawsuits over the safety of its Roundup weedkiller is stalling, plaintiffs' attorneys said Thursday in court.

title: Wisconsin Identifies Officer Who Shot Jacob Blake
summary: Police provide more details of Kenosha incident in which the 29-year-old Black man was shot in the back by a white police officer, Rusten Sheskey. KENOSHA, Wis.-The state agency charged with investigating the police shooting of Jacob Blake said Wednesday that the 29-year-old Black man admitted to having a knife in his possession. It also identified the white police officer who shot him seven times in the back, setting off several nights of violent clashes, fires and looting.

title: Oil Market's Wild Swings Subdued by Options Trading
summary: Crude prices have crept up amid OPEC production cuts and bets on reduced volatility. When Laura and Marco barreled toward Louisiana and Texas this week, companies closed more than four-fifths of offshore oil production in the Gulf of Mexico to protect equipment and personnel. Crude-oil prices barely budged.

title: Teva's Indictment Came After Talks Faltered With Justice Department
summary: In interview, CEO Kare Schultz denies allegations, criticizes former employee he says is key government witness. This week's indictment of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. 's U.S. subsidiary on price-fixing charges came after a last-minute staredown with the Justice Department in which neither side blinked.

title: Coronavirus-Aid Talks Limp Along Between Democrats, White House
summary: Democrats offer to slightly scale back their proposal. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Thursday that Democrats would be willing to accept a slightly smaller coronavirus-aid package than their previous offer, but said they remained at an impasse with the White House.

title: After Jacob Blake's Shooting, Kenosha Officials Face Criticism
summary: Residents say updates are slow and calls go unanswered; 'This is not the Alamo'. KENOSHA, Wis.-Anger is growing over how state and Kenosha officials have responded to the police shooting of Jacob Blake and the ensuing violence that has engulfed this small Midwestern city.

title: Job Seekers, Homebuyers, Stock Investors Are Expected to Benefit From Fed's New Strategy
summary: Cost of borrowing is now likely to stay low 'forever and a day'. The Federal Reserve's new strategy means that interest rates are likely to stay exceptionally low for a longer-a boon to people looking for work, buying a home or investing in stocks.

title: Trump Administration Seeks Data on Covid-19 Nursing Home Deaths
summary: Justice Department sent letters to governors in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Michigan focusing on whether coronavirus orders contributed to fatalities. The Justice Department is asking governors of four states that were hit hard early in the Covid-19 pandemic for data on certain nursing homes, as it says it is considering an investigation into how the states handled the crisis in those care settings.

title: 'Dear Liar' and 'Twelfth Night' Reviews: Love Talk
summary: A Zoom staging of the exchanges between George Bernard Shaw and Mrs. Patrick Campbell and a youth-focused production of Shakespearean comedy.. Two-character epistolary plays are well suited to the restrictive requirements of Zoom webcasting during the pandemic. Hence I admit to being surprised that it took so long for someone to revive "Dear Liar," the 1957 play that Jerome Kilty chiseled out of the correspondence of George Bernard Shaw and Mrs. Patrick Campbell, the Vicwardian actress who inscribed her name in posterity's books by creating the role of Eliza Doolittle in Shaw's "Pygmalion" at the improbable age of 49. Fortunately, Pennsylvania's Bucks County Playhouse, one of my favorite regional companies, has obliged with a very satisfying benefit reading of "Dear Liar" directed by Mark Brokaw and starring Marsha Mason and Brian Cox.

title: U.S. Government Bond Yields Rise After Fed Policy Shift
summary: Federal Reserve to drop practice of pre-emptively lifting interest rates to stave off rising inflation, but details are limited. U.S. government bond yields rose in a volatile session Thursday after the Federal Reserve formally said it would let inflation run hotter but didn't commit to buying more longer-term Treasury debt.

title: Prize Fight for TikTok Offers Uncertain Reward
summary: CEO's departure indicates deal is imminent, but battle with U.S. government might have dinged social network's value. A sale of the U.S. portion of TikTok appears imminent. But whoever ends up with the prize might rightfully wonder just what they are buying into.

title: Chen for President
summary: If China ever gains a legitimate government, who better to lead it?. Party convention speeches are often viewed as launching pads for careers in U.S. presidential politics. And this year's virtual events have featured no shortage of rising stars. Wednesday night's Republican lineup even featured an intriguing possibility for Chinese presidential politics-assuming the people of China are ever allowed to choose their leaders.

title: 'Transplant' Review: A Skilled Doctor's Second Act
summary: Now on NBC, the hit Canadian drama revolves around a Syrian émigré doctor working in a Toronto restaurant who gets an unlikely opportunity to practice medicine in his new nation.. That the Canadian hit "Transplant" is joining the prime-time NBC lineup is presumably the result of pandemically limited production schedules. But that's selling it short. The series will make its debut as the best medical show on American television, which is something given the competition (even just on NBC). And while it's a bit early for a full-blown diagnosis, it may turn out to be one of the better dramas the network has ever had.

title: Top Homeland Security Ethics Officer Warns Employees to Avoid Politics
summary: Emailed memo comes days after acting secretary Chad Wolf was featured in the Republican National Convention. The Department of Homeland Security sent an email urging employees to stay out of partisan activities after the department's acting head was featured in the Republican National Convention this week.

title: This Retro Decorating Move Will Transform Your Bedroom-for $200 or Less
summary: New, modern chenille is the perfect comfy bedspread for the Covid era and adds textural wow to your bedroom décor. MUCH LIKE VINYL kitchen chairs and shag carpeting, the texture of tufted chenille bedding can conjure a specific time and place. For Miami designer Eilyn Jimenez of Sire Design, that place is her grandmother's bedroom. Last February, in the throes of early-pandemic disquietude, Ms. Jimenez was inspired to emulate that retreat's comfort, if not its aesthetic.

title: The Lowly Asterisk Shows Its Star Quality
summary: A modest symbol long used to denote omissions or caveats has grabbed the spotlight amid the pandemic. A word denoting a mild-mannered typographical symbol has been getting a workout this year: "asterisk," that little star-shaped figure (*) most often used to mark an omission, error or annotation. With the coronavirus pandemic wreaking havoc on everything from sports schedules to academic calendars, 2020 itself is getting asterisked.

title: New York City Mayor Faces Layoff Decision as Deadline Looms
summary: City needs to close $9 billion budget gap over next two years; 22,000 workers could lose their jobs. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio faces one of the biggest challenges of his political career as he decides the fate of 22,000 government workers in danger of being laid off and tests the support of unions who helped him win office.

title: Minneapolis Police Chief Texted Activists Suicide Footage to Quell Violence
summary: 'There was so much misinformation out there,' says civil-rights activist who helped circulate video. Police leaders worked hand-in-hand with activists in Minneapolis Wednesday night to quell violent unrest sparked by misinformation about a man's suicide, after the community mistakenly thought he was shot by police.

title: Spain Weighs Legacy of Juan Carlos I After Ex-King Moves to Persian Gulf
summary: Fallen monarch helped restore Spanish democracy but is now beset by scandal and getting attention over his new home. Spain's former King Juan Carlos I surprised his country this month when he said he was going into exile amid escalating judicial investigations of his finances. His choice of new home has raised Spaniards' eyebrows further: the United Arab Emirates, in the Gulf region where his business dealings triggered the scandals that are battering his reputation.

title: The 72 Hours That Shook Kenosha and Stopped the NBA
summary: After the police shooting of Jacob Blake, athletes decided it was no longer enough to protest while playing. It was time to protest by refusing to play.. The police in Kenosha, Wis., got the call at 5:11 p.m. local time on Sunday. About five minutes later, an officer yelled breathlessly over the radio: "Shots fired!"

title: Former UAW President Is Charged With Embezzlement
summary: Dennis Williams is second United Auto Workers president to face charges in a federal probe of union corruption in auto industry. Federal prosecutors have charged former United Auto Workers President Dennis Williams with embezzlement, marking the latest escalation in a yearslong probe into corruption in the union's top ranks.

title: Dollar Stores Can't Catch a Break
summary: Both Dollar General and Dollar Tree outperformed expectations but their shares are down as questions loom around the sustainability of their recent run. Stimulus checks have the potential to whipsaw expectations for many retailers, but perhaps none more so than dollar stores.

title: Mission Impossible: Convincing a Polish Town to Let Tom Cruise Destroy Its Bridge
summary: Resume Subscription. WLEŃ, Poland-The mission seemed improbable, if not impossible: Convince the residents of a Polish town to let Tom Cruise blow up their bridge.

title: Why Tourist Spots Like Bermuda Are Offering Remote-Work Visas
summary: With offices still shut and schools in limbo, a handful of countries and resorts are inviting WFH warriors to park their laptops in more scenic surroundings. CHRIS STEVENS isn't one to put down roots. The British digital entrepreneur and travel blogger has visited 40 countries over the past 10 years, and along with his girlfriend has been riding out the Covid-19 pandemic in Australia. But now, thanks to a special new visa designed to lure remote workers just like them, the peripatetic couple is considering heading to Barbados and staying put, at least for one year.

title: Russian Prosecutors Have No Plans to Investigate Navalny Poisoning
summary: Kremlin faces growing pressure from dissident's supporters and Western governments to explain what happened to him.

title: NBA Players Will End Boycott and Resume the Playoffs
summary: After sitting out games in protest of a police shooting in Kenosha, Wis., the players elected to continue the season. NBA players decided on Thursday to resume the league's playoffs after they refused to play Wednesday in protest of a police shooting in Kenosha, Wis., a defiant action that had jeopardized the rest of the basketball season and continued to halt play in other sports leagues.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended August 22
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: A Coronavirus Lesson About the Modern State
summary: A technocratic 'fix' for cancelled A-level exams turned a health crisis into a social disaster.. London

title: The Smearing of Nikki Haley
summary: Liberal Indian-Americans accuse her of denying her heritage.. Political abuse in America comes in many flavors, few more ugly than the scorn showered by many Indian-Americans on Nikki Haley, arguably the most successful ethnic Indian politician in U.S. history.

title: Discounters Draw In Consumers Amid Economic Weakness
summary: 'What we see is very reminiscent of what we saw during the Great Recession,' Dollar General CEO says. Dollar General Corp. and Dollar Tree Inc. are aiming to draw in new consumers who are freshly scrutinizing their spending amid higher unemployment caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: With Second Stimulus Checks on Hold, Americans Spend Less at the Grocery Store
summary: End to extra unemployment benefits among reasons for recent decline in food spending. Grocery shoppers are cutting back on spending, data show, a sign that Americans are hurting for cash as the federal unemployment stimulus remains on hold for most recipients.

title: In the Caribbean and Bahamas, Turnkey Properties Are the Biggest Luxury
summary: Vacation-home buyers in hard-to-reach destinations opt for fully furnished properties. Fabrice Grinda, a tech entrepreneur and investor, visited dozens of vacation villas in Turks and Caicos in search of one that was toothbrush ready.

title: The Era of Nazi War Crime Trials Is Over
summary: Since 1945, the effort to bring Holocaust perpetrators to justice has redefined our understanding of state-sponsored evil. On July 23, a German court convicted Bruno Dey as an accessory to the murder of 5,230 people. Mr. Dey had served in the SS during World War II as a guard at Stutthof, a lesser-known Nazi concentration camp located outside of Gdansk, Poland. Bizarrely, because the 93-year-old defendant had begun his guard duties when he was just 17 years old, he was tried in juvenile court. Partly for this reason, he received a lenient sentence of two years, suspended.

title: China Coast Guard Seizes Hong Kong Activists Fleeing to Taiwan
summary: Target of investigation under national-security law was among group intercepted on speedboat. HONG KONG-China's coast guard detained a group of Hong Kong activists after intercepting a boat in the South China Sea en route to Taiwan, where the passengers planned to seek refuge from Beijing's national-security crackdown.

title: Why TikTok's CEO Is Quitting After Three Months
summary: The Trump administration has pushed TikTok's Chinese owner to sell its American operations. TikTok Chief Executive Kevin Mayer said he is leaving the social-media platform. It comes as the Trump administration has pushed for TikTok's owner, Chinese technology giant ByteDance Ltd., to sell its U.S. operations to an American buyer. Mayer, who joined TikTok about three months ago, wrote in a letter to staff: "I understand that the role that I signed up for-including running TikTok globally-will look very different as a result of the U.S. administration's action to push for a selloff of the U.S. business... I've always been globally focused in my work, and leading a global team that includes TikTok U.S. was a big draw for me."

title: Putin Says Russian Security Team Ready to Aid Belarusian Ally
summary: Belarus's President Alexander Lukashenko is grappling with massive protests after a contested election win. MOSCOW-Russia has assembled a law-enforcement team to help shore up Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko if protests against him spiral out of control, President Vladimir Putin said, giving the first indications of how Moscow might intervene to help its longstanding ally.

title: Germany Hits Pause On Reopening Amid Rising Covid-19 Infections
summary: New coronavirus cases across Europe raise fears of second wave. BERLIN-Germany on Thursday hit pause on any further loosening of coronavirus rules and introduced new restrictions, in the latest instance of a European nation moving to tackle a resurgence in infections driven by tourism and summer festivities.

title: A Turnkey Home in Nevada
summary: The owners of this five-bedroom property bought it fully furnished for roughly $3 million.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: For Sale, Furniture Included
